body:
## System details: 

`macOS 10.13.6`
```
system_profiler SPDeveloperToolsDataType
Developer:

    Developer Tools:

      Version: 10.1 (10B61)
      Location: /Applications/Xcode.app
      Applications:
          Xcode: 10.1 (14460.46)
      SDKs:
          macOS:
              10.14: (18B71)
```
`python 3.7.1`
`cython, commit 3bc22a95b4ff59ed7b19c92e531da0d37267822f`
`pythran, commit 341818b2fbd6ce2aa764fb6240ab25eb43304c80`

## Problem

I can't get a cython file with the pythran backend to compile. 

I'm not sure if the problem is cython, pythran, or somehow in my environment but with a test file that is just 

https://github.com/dedupeio/pyhacrf/blob/e351c9d263a899a3198bded00a3a7105e0ebf9f2/pyhacrf/adjacent.pyx#L1
```python
#cython: np_pythran=True
```

and a setup.py like

https://github.com/dedupeio/pyhacrf/blob/e351c9d263a899a3198bded00a3a7105e0ebf9f2/setup.py#L5-L13
```python
try:
    from Cython.Build import cythonize
    use_cython = True
except ImportError:
    use_cython = False

if use_cython:
    ext_modules = cythonize([Extension('pyhacrf.adjacent',
                                       ['pyhacrf/adjacent.pyx'])])
```

python setup.py build_ext gives me this:

```bash
>python setup.py build_ext
```

comment_data.body: Is the file you try to compile https://github.com/dedupeio/pyhacrf/blob/e351c9d263a899a3198bded00a3a7105e0ebf9f2/pyhacrf/adjacent.pyx#L1 , that is an empty python file with only the pythran directive?

Yes, I reduced it to that test case from.
https://github.com/dedupeio/pyhacrf/blob/master/pyhacrf/adjacent.pyx

On Fri, Nov 30, 2018 at 12:29 PM Adrien Guinet <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Is the file you try to compile
> https://github.com/dedupeio/pyhacrf/blob/e351c9d263a899a3198bded00a3a7105e0ebf9f2/pyhacrf/adjacent.pyx#L1
> , that is an empty python file with only the pythran directive?
>
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you authored the thread.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2739#issuecomment-443295539>, or mute
> the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAgxbUUeYa6HUMen-Ag6DF7pcPrLUSy6ks5u0XkIgaJpZM4Y6dJW>
> .
>

This is still true for 

Cython==0.29.14
pythran==0.9.5

@fgregg, based on the first error, this looks a lot like https://github.com/mapnik/python-mapnik/issues/201, which basically means a setup error on OSX side, probably not using the correct C++ toolchain or something similar?

explicitly adding the path to pythran does get it further:

```python
if use_cython:
    ext_modules = cythonize(...,
                             Extension('pyhacrf.adjacent',
                                       ['pyhacrf/adjacent.pyx'],
                                       include_dirs=[numpy.get_include(),
                                                    '/Users/fgregg/work/pyhacrf/.env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pythran'],
                                       extra_link_args=['-lm'],)])
```

but then errors out on

```bash

```
And if you look for the `type_traits` file in your filesystem, where does it lie?

got a bit further by setting the 

```
# distutils: language = c++
```
in the `.pyx` file

and setting '-std=c++11' in `extra_compile_args`

it's still not compiling but not due to linking issues (probably).
Nice! Can you share the error log?

i'll open a new issue, because I think it's unrelated.

For this issue, it would be great 

1. document a portable way to get pythran on the include path (something like `pythran.config.make_extension`)
2. have cython produce c++ files if np_pythran is present
3. document necessary extra compile args
4. have cythonize do all of this if np_pytrhan is present
5. maybe make a something like PythranExtension that can take compiled pyx files, if the user is not running cythonize.

okay, bit of breakthrough. 

when I change the directive in the pyx file from

```
#cython: infer_types=True, np_pythran=True
```

```
#cython: infer_types=True
#cython: np_pythran=True
```

then cythonize seems to do all the correct things without me having to manually set the include path for pythran or other settings.

Minimal reproducer:

```shell
cat > test.pyx << EOF
# cython: infer_types=True, np_pythran=True

import numpy as np
cimport numpy as np

def croll(np.ndarray[np.int8_t, ndim=1] state, Py_ssize_t idx):
    return np.roll(state, -idx, 0)
EOF
python cythonize.py -b test.pyx
```

@scoder I've been digging into this one without success, can you have a look, or provide hint? The suprising thing is that splitting the cython directive into

```
# cython: infer_types=True
# cython: np_pythran=True
```

indeed works fine.

rename.from: pythran directive prevents compilation with xcode 10.2
rename.to: pythran directive prevents compilation with xcode 10.1

title: pythran directive prevents compilation with xcode 10.1
